Q1 How to prepare for placements being in the third year of college? Is there any roadmap that I can follow?

Third year is the best time to take a lead in your professional career. No one enjoys college life more than a fourth-year student who gets placed by the middle of the 7th sem because they will have a lot of time to go for trips, hangouts, sleep a little extra on Sundays, etc. So, work hard in the 3rd year and enjoy your life to the fullest in the 4th year.

When it comes to the 5th sem, your top priority must be placements. 
Here is a roadmap for the 5th sem that you can follow:
1. Practice! Practice! Practice!
What? Data Structures and Algorithms.
Keep practising questions on platforms like GeeksForGeeks, Leetcode, etc. and participate in weekly contests if possible. It is okay if you don’t get the answer initially but being in touch with such questions is important. Try to solve at least 3 questions a day. 

2. Projects:
Choose a technology and start working on building a project. Keep improving it throughout the year. Web Development/App Development would be the fastest and easiest way to do a project.

3. Create and improve your GitHub and LinkedIn profile and keep it updated.

This is the roadmap if you are in the 6th sem:
1. Start learning the theory subjects like OOPS, CN, DBMS and OS. Focus more on SQL and keeps practising SQL questions on either Hackerrank or Leetcode.
2. Prepare a sexy resume and always keep it updated.
3. Most Important - Keep practising DSA.

If you didn’t get an internship in 3rd year, do not worry. Take it positively as you will have more time to prepare for placements than someone who is working as an intern in some company.
Q2 How to crack an MRC? What are the different rounds? How should I prepare for it?

MRC stands for Mass Recruiting Company. MRCs are the easiest to crack if your preparation is right and if you utilise your time well.

This is how the rounds usually go for an MRC:
-To start with, you'll have an aptitude test.
-You might have a coding test but it depends from company to company.
-Some companies also have a communication test after the coding round, this is nothing complex, all you need is a quiet place and you can see things happening the same as what you did in your English lab.

Technical Round:
Firstly, you'll have to be good at your communication skills. If you speak well and you portray yourself as a confident and able candidate, the spotlight is all yours.
Second, for the aptitude test brush up on the topics covered in the ESD classes and you can also use IndiaBix for your reference. Usually, questions of similar types as IndiaBix are asked for an MRC. Focus a bit more on logical aptitude questions which cover blood relation, encoding decoding, seating arrangement questions etc.
Third, for the coding round simple questions are asked and the types of questions depend from company to company but they might not involve a lot of DSA compared to what Dream or Superdream would ask.

And then the INTERVIEW,
Firstly, greet the interviewer, dress well, appear confident and have a smile on your face but don't grin or show your teeth. The interviewers are usually chill. Mostly all of them will ask for an introduction, and then they move on to the projects that you have worked on. Tell them about the features the project has and the technology stack used. The interviewer might also ask for some coding and these will be the most basic ones which include Fibonacci, reversing a number/string, palindrome program and other easy ones you can think of. Also, have good command over OOP concepts.

This should help you get placed in an MRC with ease! 
Good Luck
Q3 Which programming language should I learn?

Students are encouraged to know the basics of all the languages below but they need to strengthen themselves in one of the languages for problem solving.

•Java: Most used by the companies for development. They should make themselves familiar with the Collections libraries for ease in competitive coding.

•C++: Easy to learn and master. STL libraries will be very useful for DSA and competitive problems. 

•Python: Good for projects, and can be used competitively. However some companies might not have it in the IDE during the online tests.
Q4 Are certifications important? If yes, where can I earn them?

Adding certificates to your resume is completely optional. But, students are encouraged to get certifications which can be added to their resume. Some examples are Azure, AWS, React.js, etc. However, students should make sure that the certificate is from a reputed organization like Coursera, Google, Microsoft, Cisco, etc. These certifications are paid generally but they add value to your resume. 

Students are advised to stay away from certification sites like Udemy or some Small startups that give certifications, because these certifications don’t add value to your resume and companies generally don’t consider these certificates.

If you just want to learn the skills , Udemy is a good source, but you can find better sources on YouTube like LoveBabbar, freecodecamp, Striver, ProgrammingwithMosh, etc.
Q5 What are the different categories in which I can build some projects to be put in my resume?

Students are encouraged to have projects in the following categories (but not limited to) most of which might be covered in the academic year:

Web Development: It is preferable to have a web project using React and Node, rather than non-interactive websites using just HTML and CSS.

Mobile App Development: Make sure that the app that you make is useful for a group of people. Try using APIs or database or AI in the backend to increase the value of your app. 

DBMS: They can preferably do projects on management systems. They can use either SQL or No-SQL databases to implement this.

Machine Learning: Preferable projects on Data Science, Analytics and Deep Learning.

Internship Projects:
Students are especially WARNED to stay away from small companies that ask you to pay to provide internships for namesake. These internships are not worth the money since the interviewers generally ask about your internship experiences. You can look for internships on LinkedIn and Angel.co. 

What matters the most is how well you can apply whatever you have learnt.
NOTE: Don't run after internships, work on good personal projects.
Q6 How important is the aptitude and how to prepare for it?

Aptitude is one of the most important requirements for placements. Almost 90% of the companies have aptitude as part of the first round. The first round is generally the filtering round for shortlisting candidates. Out of around 200-300, they generally shortlist 50-100 in the first round or even less.

Aptitude shouldn’t be ignored just because they are considered simple problems.If a student is strong in coding but weak in aptitude, there is a less chance that he will get into the next round. So, aptitude should be given enough priority.

Some of the useful resources for aptitude preparation are given below:
IndiaBix: https://www.indiabix.com
AptitudeAcademy on Youtube: https://www.youtube.com/user/aptitudeacademy
AptitudeAcademy: http://aptitudeacademy.co.in/ 

You may also refer to a book titled 'Quantitative Aptitude' by R. S. Aggarwal. 

Important topics for Quantitative Aptitude:
• Numbers 
• LCM and HCF 
• Time and Work
• Trains
• Boats and Streams 
• Percentages 
• Ratio Proportion 
• Mixtures and Allegation 
• Average 
• Age
• Profit and Loss 
• Simple Interest
• Compound Interest 
• Volume and Surface area 
• Height and Distances 
• Logarithms
• Permutation and Combination 
• Probability 
• Clocks 
• Progressions 

Please do not neglect Qualitative Aptitude and Logical Reasoning.
Q7 How to start coding? Which are the top coding platforms?

Students can use the following coding platforms to get familiarized with the competitive coding scene.
For the students, who want to learn about the basic syntax of any coding language and basic data structures, they can use HackerRank or GeeksForGeeks. (Recommended for beginners and people starting out)
HackerRank: https://www.hackerrank.com/
GeeksForGeeks: https://practice.geeksforgeeks.org/

Once they are comfortable with the language, they can shift to LeetCode or CodeChef. A bit tough in the beginning, but once they get used to it, it will be very useful. It is recommended to start off with Easy problems and move on to higher difficulties.
LeetCode: https://leetcode.com/
CodeChef: https://www.codechef.com/

If they want to see Scenario(Paragraph)-based problems (Using an example and not having the direct problem statement), they can refer Codeforces. (Can refer, but not recommended since it is heavily focused on coding contests and not company interviews)
Codeforces: https://codeforces.com

Q9 How important is Data Structures and Algorithms? Is it a must to cover all of it in algorithms?

Data structures and algorithms form the backbone of the entire placement journey. It is a must to have a good grasp on every data structure concept starting with arrays to trees. 

Is it a must to cover all of it in algorithms? The answer is NO! Having a good understanding of time complexity is essential and the sorting algorithms and the way they work should be at your fingertips. When it comes to graphs DFS and BFS is a must other than that not most of it asked. And then comes Dynamic Programming, even googlers fear it, but what people miss out on is good tricks and tactics to approach it.

If you go out to any coding platform and filter out DP questions most of them are categorized into medium level questions and believe me they are hard. But to spit facts, if you solve certain standard problems like coin change, house robber to name a few then that should be it. DSA sheets available online have specific DP questions solved, if you can solve them then you are on good track.

Q11 How to approach a coding problem? When should I look at the solution?

Make sure you practice the right problems, and when you solve it, go full on into the problem. And one more tip here that helped me is to document all the standard problems you solve. Meaning you document the solutions that you wrote, and the optimal solutions, and short description for you to understand the logic. that'll be very helpful to revise before interviews. \n\nAnd when you're solving problems, try your best to solve them on your own, even if your solution is not optimal, code it and run it, then try to improve the logic, and if you can't, then take hints, and you still can't optimise then only refer the solution. And even after referring the solution, just look at the logic and code by yourself.
Q12 How long should I spend on a coding question if I am not being able to solve it initially?

That's a good question, the time would vary depending on how close you think you are. If you think you're getting nowhere then trying for half hour is enough. But if you're making progress then try to go all the way. Sometimes take an hour or 2. \n\nIf it's a standard problem then there's absolutely no loss in spending time on it. The more you understand the problems the better it is. Because in interviews they ask variations of standard problems and algorithms itself.
Q13 How important is it to understand the time and space complexity?

Time Complexity is the measure of time taken by a program.
Space Complexity is the measure of space used by a program.

Time & Space Complexity is one of the important things that one should keep in mind while attending interviews. One should know how to calculate the time & space complexity of a given program. This is generally asked in an interview. They may also ask you the complexities of the different sorting algorithms.

These complexities will be further helpful to decide whether you can optimize your solutions further.

Refer to the ‘Data Structures and Algorithms’ section of the app to know more about time complexity.
Q14 What are the most asked theory topics in the interviews? Where can I get the resources?

OOPS,DBMS,OS,DC & CN are some of the most asked theory topics in interviews. So students should be in touch with these concepts. Too much detail in these topics isn't necessary but they should be thorough with the core topics, e.g. in CN, OSI Model and its working is an important topic but in depths of these isn’t required.
